journal-title-group.journal-subtitle: An International Journal of Systematic Entomology

title-group.article-title: Revision of the Australian soldier fly genus Antissella White, 1914, including six new species (Stratiomyidae: Antissinae)

contrib-group.aff: 1Australian National Insect Collection, National Research Collections Australia, CSIRO, PO Box 1700 Canberra, ACT 2601, Australia
2Department of Entomology, Smithsonian Institution, c/o 8920 S Bryerly Ct., Hereford, AZ 85615, USA

permissions.copyright-holder: Koninklijke Brill NV incorporates the imprints Brill, Brill Nijhoff, Brill Hotei, Brill Schöningh, Brill Fink, Brill mentis, Vandenhoeck & Ruprecht, Böhlau Verlag and V&R Unipress.

abstract.title: Abstract
abstract.p: Antissella White, 1914 is a small genus of soldier flies endemic to Australia, previously thought to comprise only two described species and suspected to have a role in pollination. Six new species of Antissella are named, described and illustrated herein, and an updated identification key to all known species is provided. The new species include: Antissella alicespringsensis Lessard & Woodley sp.n., Antissella elongata Lessard & Woodley, sp.n., Antissella kalbarriensis Lessard & Woodley sp.n., Antissella nigricentralis Lessard & Woodley sp.n., Antissella ottensorum Lessard & Woodley, sp.n., and Antissella purprasina Lessard & Woodley, sp.n. A lectotype and paralectotype are also selected for Antissella quinquecella (Macquart, 1846). Eight species of Antissella are now recognised from Australia. Three of the new species are known from areas burned by the devastating 2019/2020 Australian summer bushfires. Now that they are formally named and described, the species may be recognised in future bushfire recovery monitoring programs.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: The Stratiomyidae are a cosmopolitan family of Diptera, with eight subfamilies recognised in Australia (Woodley 2001). Adults are known to visit flowers (Lessard et al. 2019), whereas the larvae feed on decaying organic matter (Lessard et al. 2020b), occasionally becoming pests of agricultural crops (Lessard et al. 2020a). The Antissinae are a small subfamily of colourful metallic soldier flies, currently defined by the middle legs with a tibial spur present and male terminalia with large, explanate gonostyli (Woodley 2001). The subfamily comprises 25 species described in eight genera distributed in Australia, New Guinea, South America and the Nearctic (Woodley 2001; Lessard et al. 2020c). Five genera are endemic to Australia, including Anacanthella Macquart, 1855, Antissa Walker, 1854, Antissella White, 1914, Lecomyia White, 1916 and the recently described Opaluma Lessard & Woodley, 2020 (Woodley 2001; Lessard et al. 2020c).

Members of Antissella are relatively elongate, green to coppery red flies. The genus is widespread throughout Australia, occurring in every state and territory (Fig. 1). Based on collection records, Antissella is found in a variety of habitats including shrubland, dry sclerophyll forests and rainforests. The biology of the genus is relatively unknown, although the genus is expected to have an unappreciated role in pollination as museum specimens have been collected from flowers of Correa (Rutaceae), Choretrum (Santalaceae) and Eucalyptus (Myrtaceae).

caption.p: Distribution of Antissella White, 1914. act, Australian Capital Territory; NSW, New South Wales; nt, Northern Territory; Qld, Queensland; SA, South Australia; Tas, Tasmania; Vic, Victoria; WA, Western Australia.

sec.p: Until recently, the taxonomic knowledge of the Australian Stratiomyidae was historically poor, hindered by a waning interest in the family (Lessard et al. 2018). In the past century, many undescribed species of Antissinae were collected, but left unidentified in entomological collections (Lessard et al. 2020c). Only two described species of Antissella were recognised prior to this study. White (1914) originally proposed the genus as monotypic for Antissella parvidentata (Macquart, 1850), stating that is was similar to Antissa based on the presence of rudimentary spines (referred to from hereon as marginal denticles), but could be separated by the longer antennae being twice the length of the head (White 1914, 1916). Woodley (2001) later transferred Antissella quinquecella (Macquart, 1846) into the genus from its previous placement in Lecomyia. In this paper, we describe, name and illustrate six new species of Antissella, quadrupling the size of the genus, and provide an updated key to all eight species now recognised from Australia.

sec.title: Materials and methods
sec.p: Specimens were examined using a Zeiss dissecting microscope and photographed on a Dun Inc. bk Imaging ‒ plus Lab System using a Canon 65 mm lens. Images were stacked in Zerene Stacker v 1.0 software and processed in Adobe Photoshop CS6 to obtain a fully sharpened image.

Genitalia were prepared by dissecting from the apical portion of the abdomen that was placed in koh at 70°C and allowed to incubate overnight at room temperature, followed by a wash in distilled water. Genitalia were examined in glycerine then transferred to ky jelly and imaged on a Leica M205A microscope and stacked using Zerene Stacker v 1.0 software. Genitalia were then placed in glycerine and stored in microvials pinned below each specimen.

Morphological terminology follows Cumming & Wood (2017) and Hauser et al. (2017). Body lengths are given exclusive of antennae. Frontal index was calculated by dividing the length of the anterior ocellus to the base of the antennae by the width of the middle frons (note: the description of frontal index was wrongly transposed as frons width divided by length previously in Lessard et al. 2018, 2019, 2020a, 2020b, 2020c).

Holotype specimen labels are quoted verbatim (i.e. “xx”) and individual lines are separated by forward slashes (/). Type specimens were imaged for all species. As the original type specimens of A. parvidentata and A. quinquecella are in poor condition, additional images are provided for more recently collected museum specimens, and the redescription of each species is completed using additional non-type material. Novel type material is deposited in collections presented in square parentheses ([]). A distribution map for each species of Antissella was generated in BioLink version 3 software and presented in Fig. 1. Bushfire data for the 2019/2020 season was obtained from the National Indicative Aggregated Fire Extent Dataset (DAWE 2020).

def.p: Australian National Insect Collection, csiro, Canberra, Australia
Laboratoire d’Entomologie, Muséum National d’Histoire Naturelle, Paris, France
Richard Glatz Private Collection, Kangaroo Island, South Australia
Entomology, South Australian Museum, Adelaide, Australia

sec.title: Genus Antissella White, 1914
sec.p: (Figs 2–17)

sec.p: Antissella White, 1914: 52. Type species, Beris parvidentata Macquart, 1850, by monotypy. For complete synonymy see Woodley (2001: 76). Hardy (as Clitellariinae, tribe Antissini in 1920: 52 and 1932: 46); White (1916: 81); Woodley (1989: 305).

Diagnosis. Relatively slender, green to coppery red flies, most similar to Anacanthella, but distinguished by the more elongate abdomen, 1.25 times longer than wide, moderately wider frons in the females (index 1.9–2.3), thorax dark bluish green to coppery red, with relatively sparse, erect hair-like setae, and scutellum with 8–12 obvious marginal denticles.

Antissella can be separated from other world antissine genera by its scutellum with marginal denticles present (as opposed to elongate spines), and specifically from: Discopteromyia de Meijere, 1913 (New Guinea) by the shorter antennae, less than 1.5 times the length of head (longer, about twice as long as length of head in Discopteromyia) and presence of wing vein M3 (absent in Discopteromyia; Meijere 1913; James 1978), and; Cyanauges Rondani, 1863 (Brazil and Chile) and Exodontha Rondani, 1856 (Nearctic and Palearctic) by the longer antennae, 1.2 times as long as head length, with elongate, cylindrical and well defined flagellomeres, and apical flagellomeres short, thick and blunt (antennae shorter than head length, with more compressed flagellomeres in Cyanauges and Exodontha; Cyanauges with apical flagellomeres slender, style-like; Nagatomi 1968; James 1973).

Description. Length 5–11.5 mm. Male. Length 5–8 mm Head: Eyes dichoptic, usually separated by at least the width of anterior ocellus (as wide as ocellar tubercle only in Antissella elongata Lessard & Woodley, sp.n.), relatively small, approximately 0.8 times as wide as thorax, ommatidia slightly wider anteriorly, large, occupying most of head in lateral view. Frons reduced, shining metallic, widest at upper frons, 0.15–0.3 times the width of the head at anterior ocellus, distinctly converging ventrally, with dense, hair-like setae and bare dorsal area; vertex diverging posteriorly, shining metallic. Face not visible in lateral view, semi-shining, with dense, long, hair-like setae. Antennae moderately long, usually about 1.2 times length of head (1.5 times length in A. elongata Lessard & Woodley, sp.n.); scapes 1.0–1.4 times length of pedicels, both segments covered in short, black hair-like setae; flagellae usually 1.4–2.0 times length of scape+pedicel (3.5 times length in A. elongata Lessard & Woodley, sp.n.). Palpi with second segment cylindrical to ovoid, blunted apically.

Thorax: Scutum elongate, scutum+scutellum 1.2–1.5 as long as wide, green with reflections of blue to coppery red, without tomentum or distinct patterns, covered in erect and some appressed hair-like setae; scutellum same colour as scutum, margins rounded, with 8–12 marginal denticles, occasionally obscured by long, dense hair-like setae. Legs unmodified. Wings smoky yellowish brown to slightly hyaline; R1 relatively straight to slightly sinuous; R4 curved to sinuous, vein M3 terminating half to three quarters distance to wing margin, all other M veins weakening, almost or completely reaching wing margin.

Abdomen: Truncate ovoid, usually about 1.25 times as long as wide, occasionally elongate, 1.7 times as long as wide (as in Antissella purprasina Lessard & Woodley sp.n.), or relatively short, 0.8 times as long as wide (only in Antissella kalbarriensis Lessard & Woodley, sp.n.), with brilliant reflections of copper, purple, blue and/or green, tergites covered in short, relatively dense hair-like setae, with long, erect hair-like setae towards lateral margins, most obvious at basal tergites. Sternites shining, with reflections of copper to green, with marginal sublateral indentations, covered in short, appressed hair-like setae, long and erect at centre of sternites. Terminalia: brown with hair-like setae moderately long, yellowish or brown; gonostyli dorsoventrally flattened, lateral margins relatively straight, posterior margins usually tapering; gonocoxites tapering anteriorly, posterior margin of synsternite with a pair of medial processes; phallic complex trifid, with medial lobe exceeding length of lateral lobes, with parameral sheath present, usually slender, exceeding length of phallic complex and distinctly tapering posteriorly.

Female. Length 5–11.5 mm. Similar to male, but with the following differences: covered in shorter, sparser, more appressed hair-like setae. Frons narrow to relatively wide (index 1.5–2.4), margins parallel to slightly converging ventrally on upper four fifths of frons length, lower fifth of frons with margins diverging ventrally, cuticular surface shining, without tomentum, relatively bare, with a patch of dense, hair-like setae at lateral margins of middle third. Thorax covered in short, more appressed than erect, hair-like setae, not as densely covered as in males. Cerci yellowish brown, two-segmented, second segment elongate and ovoid, bluntly rounded at tip, covered in long, yellowish brown hair-like setae.
Distribution. The genus is known from all Australian states and territories (Fig. 1) and recorded from a range of habitats including shrubland, dry sclerophyll forests and rainforests.

Remarks. At least two putatively undescribed species are known from collections that can be separated by their small size (length 5 mm), relatively stout bodies and dull colouration. Both are formed from a series of singleton specimens spanning diverse geographical locations. The first is a Western Australian population known from three females and one male (female, Margaret River, AMS K504386; female, Bunbury, AMS K504385; male, Watheroo np, ANIC 29-037464; and female, nr. Dongara, ANIC 29-037465). The second is an eastern population known from a single female specimen from Barren Grounds Nature Reserve, NSW (ANIC 29-037466), and a single male specimen from Little Desert np, Vic (ANIC 29-037467). These potentially undescribed species are left untreated until more specimens become available.

sec.title: Key to species for both sexes of Antissella

list-item.p:
Antennae long, flagellae more than 3 times as long as scape+pedicel; males with widely dichoptic eyes, lower frons as wide as ocellar tubercle; nt (Fig. 12)…………….………………………………… elongata Lessard & Woodley, sp.n.
‒
Antennae shorter, flagellae never exceeding twice the length of scape+pedicel; males with narrowly dichoptic eyes, lower frons width less than that of ocellar tubercle ……………………………………………………………………………………2

Thorax with dull purple anterior half, sharply contrasting greenish gold posterior half; legs dark brown to black; abdomen elongate, about 1.7 times as long as wide; Qld (Fig. 9)……………………………………. purprasina Lessard & Woodley sp.n.
‒
Thorax concolorous, usually bluish green, golden or coppery red; legs yellowish; abdomen ovoid, about 1.25 times as long as wide…………..………….………………….……….…………………………… 3

Eyes in males almost touching, separated by less than the width of anterior ocellus, with short, hair-like setae that are less than width of antennal flagellae; females with relatively wide frons (index 1.5) with margins almost parallel; abdomen with bright purplish hues at anteromedial centre, reddish laterally; Kangaroo Island, SA (Figs 10 and 11).…………………………….… ottensorum Lessard & Woodley, sp.n.
‒
Eyes in males distinctly separated by more than the width of anterior ocellus, with long, hair-like setae that are equal to width of antennal flagellae; females with relatively narrow frons (index 1.9–2.3), margins converging ventrally; abdomen not as above, usually coppery red or gold to green. Mainland Australia and/or Tas………………………………………………………….…… 4

Thorax and abdomen brilliant golden green; abdomen relatively short and wide, 0.8 times as long as wide; WA (Fig. 13)……………….………………….… ………………………………………………kalbarriensis Lessard & Woodley sp.n.
‒
Thorax and abdomen with shades of blue, purple or copper; abdomen slender, elongate, more than 1.1 times as long as wide……………………………. 5

Abdomen with a distinct black medial zone; WA (Figs 14 and 15)…………………………………………. nigricentralis Lessard & Woodley sp.n.
‒
Abdomen concolorous, without distinct black markings………………………6

Antennal flagellae black; legs mostly dark brown, with wide, contrasting yellow femoral-tibial joints; nt (Figs 16 and 17)…………………………………………………………………………… alicespringsensis Lessard & Woodley sp.n.
‒
Antennal flagellae yellowish brown; legs concolorous yellowish; south-eastern Australia and Tas………………………………………………….…………………7

Thorax bluish green, usually contrasting with copper to golden abdomen; legs with dark brown coxae, contrasting pale yellowish brown femora, tibiae and tarsomeres; males with relatively wide frons, width at anterior ocellus about twice the width of ocellar tubercle, lower frons wider than anterior ocellus (Figs 5–8)…………..………………………………………………….… quinquecella (Macquart, 1846)
‒
Thorax and abdomen almost concolorous dull copper to purplish; legs, including coxae, concolorous pale yellowish brown; males with narrow frons, width at anterior ocellus about equal to width of ocellar tubercle, lower frons almost contiguous, eyes separated by less than width of anterior ocellus (Figs 2–4)……………………………………………………………………………… parvidentata (Macquart, 1850)

sec.p: (Figs 2–4)
Type material examined. Holotype ♀, Beris parvidentata Macquart, 1850: 344, “Beris/parvidentata/♀. Macq. n. sp./Tasm”; “3 [over] 47” [mnhn; Fig. 2]. In poor condition.

Diagnosis. A dull metallic coppery purple species with yellow legs, similar to A. quinquecella, but distinguished by the legs including coxae concolorous pale yellowish brown, and thorax and abdomen concolorous dull coppery purple, usually without any obvious bluish reflections. Males with relatively narrow frons, width at anterior ocellus about the same width of ocellar tubercle, and lower frons almost contiguous, less than width of anterior ocellus, with a medial, almost linear tuft of dense white hair-like setae.

Redescription. Length 6–8.5 mm. Male. Length 6.5–7.5 mm. Head: Eyes almost contiguous at lower frons, separated by less than the width of anterior ocellus, with moderately long, dense, pale brownish hair-like setae. Occiput black, with subtle greenish blue and coppery red reflections, hair-like setae brownish black on upper half, whitish on lower half. Frons narrow, less than the width of ocellar tubercle at anterior ocellus, upper frons shining black, with long, dense blackish hair-like setae, lower frons covered in a long, dense, almost linear tuft of white hair-like setae. Face black, subshining, with long, dense white setae. Antennal scapes and pedicels yellowish brown, pedicels about 1.1–1.3 times as long as scapes, hair-like setae short, dense black; flagellae dark brown, becoming paler yellowish brown on inner surface. Palpi dark brown to black, with long, dense, dark brown to black hair-like setae. Proboscis black with predominantly pale brown hair-like setae.

Thorax: Scutum with reflections of dull, predominantly coppery reddish to purple, occasionally with additional subtle greenish or golden reflections, hair-like setae long, erect, predominantly white, slightly more yellowish on dorsal surface; scutellum same colour and hair-like setae as scutum; pleura same colour as scutum, hair-like setae whitish. Legs with coxae yellowish brown with white hair-like setae; femora, tibiae and tarsomeres concolorous pale yellowish brown, darkening slightly on apical tarsi, hair-like setae white, more erect on femora. Wings hyaline to slightly yellowish; stigma yellowish; veins pale yellowish brown; vein M3 terminating two thirds distance to wing margin; halteres cream to brown, slightly darker on stem.

Abdomen: Same colour as scutum, hair-like setae pale yellowish to white, short and appressed on cuticular surface, becoming longer and more erect laterally. Sternites same colour as tergites, hair-like setae short, appressed, white.

Female. Length 6–8.5 mm. Similar to male, but with the following differences: eyes with shorter hair-like brown setae; frons relatively narrow (index 1.8–2.7), margins parallel-sided, only slightly converging ventrally, cuticular surface shining, with reflections of coppery red, with patches of dense, moderately long, white hair-like setae at lateral margins of middle half of frons, bare elsewhere; thorax with shorter, dense, appressed hair-like setae; cerci yellowish brown, second segment elongate ovoid, about equal in length to first segment, with moderately long yellowish hair-like setae.
Distribution. This species overlaps in distribution with A. quinquecella, occurring throughout act, NSW, Tas and Vic (Fig. 1).

Remarks. Namadgi National Park, act, was severely burned in the recent 2019/2020 summer bushfires which may have impacted local populations of A. parvidentata and A. quinquecella that co-occur in the region.
(Figs 5–8)

Type material examined. Lectotype ♀, Beris quinquecella Macquart, 1846: 175, “Beris/5.cella/Macq. n. sp.”; “74”; “13 [over] 44” [mnhn; Fig. 5]. In poor condition, antennal flagellae present. Originally a syntype, hereby designated as the lectotype.

Paralectotype ♀, Beris quinquecella Macquart, 1846: 175, same label information as Lectotype, being mounted together on a larger block of pith [mnhn; Fig. 6]. In poor condition, antennal flagellae missing. Originally a syntype, hereby designated as the paralectotype.

Diagnosis. A brilliant shining bluish green and coppery gold species, similar to A. parvidentata, but distinguished by the bluish green thorax, usually contrasting golden and copper abdomen, and legs with dark brown coxae, contrasting pale yellowish remaining segments. Males with relatively wide frons, width at anterior ocellus about twice the width of ocellar tubercle, lower frons wider than anterior ocellus, with lateral tufts of sparser white hair-like setae along eye margins.

Redescription. Length 6.5–8.5 mm. Male. Length 6.5–8.5 mm. Head: Eyes separated by more than the width of anterior ocellus, with long, dense brown hair-like setae. Occiput black with predominantly bluish purple reflections, hair-like setae black dorsally, white ventrally. Frons relatively wide, wider than ocellar tubercle at anterior ocellus, upper frons black, shining, with slight reflections of greenish blue, with long, dense, blackish hair-like setae, lower frons with lateral tufts of whitish hair like setae along eye margins, relatively bare in between (most visible in dorsal view). Face black, subshining, with long, dense, white hair-like setae. Antennal scapes and pedicels pale yellowish brown, pedicels relatively short, about 0.75–1.0 times as long as scapes, both segments with dense, relatively long black hair-like setae; flagellae brown, slightly paler brown along inner surface. Palpi black, with long, dense, brown and black hair-like setae. Proboscis black with dark brown and black hair-like setae.

Thorax: Scutum with predominantly blue or greenish gold reflections, occasionally coppery red, hair-like setae long, erect, pale yellow, with small patches of more appressed whitish sublateral vittae at anterior edge; scutellum same colour as scutum, reflections often deeper bluish green, hair-like setae predominately yellowish; pleura black, with dull, more subtle reflections of blue, purple, greenish gold or coppery red, hair-like setae long, dense, whitish. Legs with coxae dark brown, with long, dense, whitish hair-like setae; femora, tibiae and tarsomeres yellowish brown, hair-like setae white, usually longer on femora. Wings hyaline, slightly smoky brown; stigma yellowish; veins yellowish brown; vein M3 terminating two thirds distance to wing margin; halteres pale yellowish brown, darker on stem.

Abdomen: Shining, with reflections of bright coppery red, green and gold, occasionally bluish purple, hair-like setae pale yellow, short, appressed on cuticular surface, erect, long at lateral margins. Sternites same colour as tergites, hair-like setae usually white at centre of sternites 1–3, yellow elsewhere.

Female. Length 6.5–8 mm. Similar to male, but with the following differences: frons relatively narrow (index 2–3.1), margins parallel-sided, converging ventrally, cuticular surface shining black, with subtle reflections of bluish green or coppery red, with patches of dense, moderately long, white hair-like setae at lateral margins of middle half of frons, bare elsewhere; thorax with shorter, more appressed hair-like setae; cerci yellowish brown, second segment elongate ovoid, about equal in length to first segment, with moderately long yellowish hair-like setae.
Distribution. Widespread throughout south eastern Australia, ranging from southeast Qld, to coastal NSW, act, Vic and Tas (Fig. 1).

Remarks. Historically, there was some doubt as to the placement of A. quinquecella. The species was first described in the beridine genus Beris Latreille, 1802 (Macquart 1846). It was unrecognised by White (1914, 1916) in the description of Antissella, perhaps because he did not have access to the type material. Hardy (1920, 1932) later transferred A. quinquecella to Lecomyia and went as far as incorrectly synonymising Lecomyia caerulea White, 1914 under it. More recently, A. quinquecella was transferred to Antissella by Woodley (1989: 305) where it currently remains.

The identification of A. parvidentata and A. quinquecella has been difficult due to a lack of robust identification keys, accurately identified specimens, thorough descriptions and poor condition of the type specimens. This may be attributed to the degree of overlap in the south eastern geographical distribution (act, NSW, Tas and Vic) and brief descriptions provided by Macquart (1846, 1850) who described both species as having coppery red frons, antennal scapes and pedicels brownish, thorax coppery with green hues, scutellum (although not directly mentioned) with very small denticles, abdomen coppery, and wings with five posterior cells present (i.e. cells r5 and m1–m4). The only discernible difference in Macquart’s original descriptions is that the face is black in A. parvidentata and coppery violet in A. quinquecella. On examination of the types and material held across Australian collections, we can confirm that A. parvidentata and A. quinquecella are two valid species and can be separated based on the morphological characters presented in the updated key and species diagnoses.

sec.title: Antissella purprasina Lessard & Woodley, sp.n.
sec.p: (Fig. 9)
ZooBank: http://zoobank.org/610641F7-20A5-45A1-B92F-168E68D69182
Material examined. Holotype ♀, “National Park., Q./H.Hacker./Dec. 1923”; “holotype ♀/Antissella purprasina Lessard & Woodley 2021”; “QM Reg. No./T246799” [QM]. The specimen is in good condition.

Paratypes: ♀, “QLD: 28.192°S X153.124°E/Lamington NP, IBISCA 700B,/9Nov–2Dec 2008. Malaise/RF, G.Monteith”; “paratype ♀/Antissella purprasina Lessard & Woodley 2021”; “QM Reg. No./T246800” [QM]. ♀, “QLD: 28.192°S X153.124°E/Lamington NP, IBISCA 700B,/6–22Jan 2009. Malaise/RF, G.Monteith”; “paratype ♀/Antissella purprasina Lessard & Woodley 2021”; “QM Reg. No./T246801” [QM]. ♀, “QLD: 28.193°S X153.128°E/Lamington NP, IBISCA 700c,/9Nov–2Dec 2008. Malaise/RF, G.Monteith”; “paratype ♀/Antissella purprasina Lessard & Woodley 2021”; “anic Database No./29 037463” [anic, with permission from QM]. These specimens are in excellent condition.

Diagnosis. An elongate green and black species, most similar to A. parvidentata, but distinguished by the slender, elongate abdomen, 1.7 times as long as wide, scutum with anterior half black with purple reflections, sharply contrasting with the posterior half with deep green reflections and dense golden hair-like setae, legs with black femora and tibiae, and abdomen black without obvious metallic reflections.

Description. Male. Unknown. Female. Length 8.5–11.5 mm. Head: Eyes covered in short, brown hair-like setae. Occiput black, hair-like setae pale yellowish brown dorsomedially, becoming black laterally. Frons narrow (index 1.9), margins almost parallel-sided, cuticular surface shining black, with relatively sparse, whitish hair-like setae. Face shining black, with white hair-like setae. Antennal scapes and pedicels pale yellowish brown, with short, brown hair-like setae; flagellae slightly yellowish brown, slightly paler on inner surface. Palpi dark brown to black, with long, black hair-like setae. Proboscis dark brown to black, with dark brown hair-like setae.

Thorax: Scutum shining purple in front of transverse suture, with short, dense, appressed, brown hair-like setae, shining green behind transverse suture, with dense, short, golden hair-like setae; scutellum shining green, with short, dense, predominantly appressed, golden hair-like setae, with four marginal denticles; pleura predominantly black, with subtle reflections of bluish green, hair-like setae white. Legs with coxae dark brown to black, with whitish hair-like setae; femora and tibiae dark brown to black, with basal area of femora yellowish, hair-like setae white; tibiae yellowish brown, paler on mid legs, hair-like setae white on outer surface and golden brown on inner surface. Wings slightly smoky brown to hyaline, with a subtle brown infuscation on the apical third of cell br; stigma yellowish; M3 terminating two thirds distance to margin; halteres pale yellowish brown.

Abdomen: Elongate, about 1.7 times as long as wide, dull dark brown, without obvious colourful metallic reflections, hair-like setae predominantly short, appressed, dark brown, with white slightly longer, erect, white hair-like setae at lateral margins of tergites 1–3. Sternites same colour as tergites, hair-like setae short, appressed, white, becoming darker brown apically, sternite 2 with a distinct medial undulation, and sternite 5 with a posteroventrally pointed medial process. Cerci dark brown to black, with mixed dark brown and yellowish brown setae, second segment long, narrow and elongate, about 5 times as long as wide.
Etymology. This specific name is derived from the Latin, purpre, purple, and prasinus, green, referring to the contrasting purple and green thorax.

Remarks. This species overlaps in distribution with A. quinquecella, both occurring from Binna Burra, Lamington np (ANIC 29-037387). The species shares the posteroventrally pointed medial process on sternite 5 also found in two undescribed species of Lecomyia from the Blue Mountains, NSW, and Main Range np, Qld, respectively, although it can be easily separated from Lecomyia by the scutellum without distinct marginal spines. The type locality of Lamington National Park was badly burned in the 2019/2020 spring and summer Australian bushfires.
Distribution. Known only from the type location of Lamington National Park, se Qld (Fig. 1).

sec.title: Antissella ottensorum Lessard & Woodley, sp.n.
sec.p: ZooBank: http://zoobank.org/99906CAC-CE87-482D-8E09-50D147CF8D0D

Material examined. Holotype ♂, “S. Aust., Boobook Hill/Reserve, se Kangaroo Is./21-Mar-2008 R. Glatz/9176”; “Quick flight around/foliage before landing on/it. One specimen on Correa backhousiana: one specimen on Choretrum glomeratum/9176”; “holotype ♂/Antissella ottensorum Lessard & Woodley 2021”; [originally rgc, now deposited in SAMA 29-005719]. The specimen is in excellent condition.

Paratypes: ♂, same data as Holotype (on same pin as Holotype, bottom); “paratype ♂/Antissella ottensorum Lessard & Woodley 2021”; [RGC 9176]. ♂, “S. Aust., Boobook Hill/Reserve, se Kangaroo Is./4-Apr-2007 R.V. Glatz/35°50.628S/137°56.896E 6231”; “paratype ♂/Antissella ottensorum Lessard & Woodley 2021”; [RGC 6231]. ♂, “S. Aust. Boobook Hill/Reserve, se Kangaroo Is./27-Nov-2005 R.V. Glatz net/3935”; “On (or near) blossom of/Eucalyptus rugosa sp 3935”; “paratype ♂/Antissella ottensorum Lessard & Woodley 2021”; [originally rgc, now SAMA 29-005720]. ♂, “S. Aust., house site at Lot 51/Three Chain Rd., ~6km W/D’Estrees Bay, ~1km W/Elsegood Rd., se Kangaroo Is./12-Mar-2013 R.V. Glatz/35°54.620’S/137°33.018’E 13273”; “To metal halide light 13273”; “paratype ♂/Antissella ottensorum Lessard & Woodley 2021”; “ANIC Database No./29 037468” [ANIC, with permission from R. Glatz]. ♀, Same data as previous (on same pin, top); “PARATYPE ♀/Antissella ottensorum Lessard & Woodley 2021”; [ANIC, with permission from R. Glatz]. ♀, “S. Aust., Boobook Hill/Reserve, se Kangaroo Is./17-Mar-2008 R.V. Glatz/35°50.628S/137°56.896E 9143”; “To black uv light”; “paratype ♀/Antissella ottensorum Lessard & Woodley 2021”; [originally rgc, now SAMA 29-005721]. These specimens are in excellent condition.

Diagnosis. A dark coppery red species, distinguished from A. parvidentata by the smaller size, deep golden to coppery red thorax, relatively more purplish abdomen, and eyes of males close to touching at ventral half of frons, with short hair-like setae that are less than the length of antennal scapes.

Description. Length 6–7 mm. Male. Length 6.5 mm. Head: Eyes with moderately dense, short brownish hair-like setae. Occiput dark coppery to green, with relatively dense brown hair-like setae on dorsal ridge, remainder with longer, whitish hair-like setae. Frons shining black, dorsal half bare, lower frons covered in relatively long, dense, whitish hair-like setae. Face black, covered in slight tomentum, with relatively dense, long, whitish setae. Antennae with scapes and pedicels yellowish brown, with short, black hair-like setae; flagellae black, with black tomentum, yellowish brown on the inner surface of basal flagellomeres. Palpi with both segments dark brown to black, slender, cylindrical, second segment slightly pointed at tip, with relatively dense, long, dark brown hair-like setae. Proboscis brown to black, with long, brown hair-like setae.

Thorax: Deep coppery red with greenish golden reflections at lateral margins, with relatively dense, appressed and longer erect, pale golden yellow hair-like setae; scutellum same colour as scutum, broad, with appressed and longer erect, pale golden yellow hair-like setae; pleura same colour as scutum, shining, with pale yellowish to white hair-like setae. Legs with coxae yellow to golden brown, with pale yellowish to white hair-like setae; femora yellow to golden brown, with yellowish hair-like setae; tibiae and tarsi yellowish to golden brown, somewhat paler at joints, tarsomeres darkening apically, with short, yellowish hair-like setae, occasionally darker brown dorsally on hind tarsi. Wings hyaline to slightly greyish brown, with brown infuscation on cell br; stigma yellowish brown; veins olive brown; vein M3 terminating two thirds distance to wing margin; halteres pale yellowish brown, stem slightly paler.

Abdomen: Deep coppery red with slight purple and greenish reflections, with short, appressed, whitish gold hair-like setae, longer and more erect along lateral margins of all tergites, most distinct on tergite 2. Sternites same colour as tergites, with short, relatively dense, appressed, whitish gold hair-like setae. Terminalia: gonocoxites wider than long, posterior margin of synsternite with medial processes separated by a wide, moderately deep concave emargination, gonocoxal apodemes elongate and slender, extending beyond anterior margin of gonocoxites, tapering anteriorly; phallic complex long, exceeding length of genital capsule, all three lobes of moderate thickness, medial lobe expanded posteriorly, parameral sheath relatively slender, gently curving inwards posteriorly; epandrium relatively narrow, tapering anteriorly, cerci moderately rounded posteriorly, long, slightly exceeding length of proctiger which is triangular.

Female. Length 6–7 mm. Similar to male, but with the following differences: frons relatively narrow (index 2.3–2.4), margins almost parallel, slightly converging ventrally, cuticular surface shining, black, relatively bare, with short, dense, silvery white hair-like setae at lateral margins of middle half of frons; palpi pale brown, with dense, relatively long, whitish setae; thorax with short, more appressed and fewer erect, pale golden yellow hair-like setae; abdomen less dorsoventrally compressed than males, with sparser, appressed, whitish gold hair-like setae; cerci yellowish brown, second segment ovoid, about 1.6 times as long as wide, shorter than first segment, with moderately long, relatively dense, yellowish brown hair-like setae.
Distribution. Found only on Kangaroo Island, SA (Fig. 1).
Etymology. This specific name is in honour of Jack Ottens and his family.
Biology. This species is associated with vegetation, as specimens have been collected from native plants, including Correa backhousiana, Choretrum glomeratum and Eucalyptus rugosa.

Remarks. One specimen from Boobook Hill Reserve (RGC 3935) is deeper purple in colouration, with a more robust and convex thorax, concolorous black antennae, and with darker black hind tarsomeres. This is currently interpreted as intraspecific variation.

sec.title: Antissella elongata Lessard & Woodley, sp.n.
sec.p: ZooBank: http://zoobank.org/60AB8415-5DAD-4FBE-B5CF-6AFDFC10EA96

Material examined. Holotype ♂, “25.46S 133.17E/8 km N of Kulgera,/NT 21 Sept. 1978/J.C.Cardale”; “holotype ♂/Antissella elongata Lessard & Woodley 2021”; “ANIC Database No./29 037440” [ANIC]. The specimen is in good condition.

Diagnosis. A slender black species, distinguished from all other species in the genus by the extremely long antennae with flagellae that are more than 3 times the length of the scape+pedicel and males with widely dichoptic eyes with frons as wide as ocellar tubercle (index 1.8)

Description. Male. Length 5 mm. Head: Eyes covered in short, relatively sparse, whitish hair-like setae, less than width of antennal scapes, widely dichoptic. Occiput relatively wide and obvious, visible in dorsal view, cuticular surface black with reflections of golden green, hair-like setae dense, moderately long silvery white. Frons relatively wide (index 1.8), margins converging below, cuticular surface black with reflections of golden green, hair-like setae dense, moderately long, silvery white. Face black, with golden to green reflections, tomentose, with a linear bare medial area, hair-like setae long, dense, silvery white, most obvious at centre immediately below antennae and above oral margin. Antennal scapes and pedicels dark brown to black, with short, dense, black hair-like setae, scapes about 1.25 times as long as pedicels; flagellae long, 3.5 times as long as scape+pedicel, dark brown to black, paler on inner surface, flagellomeres 2 and above covered in pale tomentum and small, dense, whitish, irregular circular markings that are presumably sensory areas. Palpi brown, with dense, relatively long brown hair-like setae, second segment only half the length of first, relatively tapered apically. Proboscis black, with pale brown labellum, with dark brown hair-like setae.

Thorax: Scutum black, with subtle reflections of blue, golden green, copper and purple, hair-like setae long, dense, silvery white; scutellum with colour and hair-like setae as on scutum, armed with eight marginal denticles; pleura black, with subtle reflections of golden green, hair-like setae long, dense, silvery white. Legs with coxae dark brown with long white hair-like setae; femora brown, paler yellowish towards joints, hair-like setae pale yellowish; tibiae brown with yellowish hair-like setae; tarsomeres yellowish brown, darkening apically on each leg, hair-like setae dense, short, mixed brown and yellowish. Wings hyaline; stigma pale brown; veins brown; M3 terminating half distance to wing margin; halteres pale yellowish white, stem darker.

Abdomen: Black with subtle reflections of bluish to greenish gold, hair-like setae short, appressed, black, with longer, erect white hair-like setae at lateral margins. Sternites same colour and reflections as tergites, hair-like setae moderately long, dense, white. Terminalia: externally protruding in specimen: gonostyli with ventral margin slightly curved inwards, apical margin slightly tapering, but blunted apically; gonocoxites wider than long, posterior margin of synsternite with semi-triangular medial processes, longer than wide, separated by a deep concave emargination; phallic complex long, exceeding length of genital capsule, medial lobe cylindrical; cerci relatively short, rounded posteriorly, in line with triangular proctiger, which is slightly rounded posteriorly.
Female. Unknown.
Distribution. Known only from the type locality of the Kulgera region, central nt (Fig. 1).
Etymology. This specific name is derived from the Latin, elongatus, prolonged, referring to the distinct elongated antennae.

sec.title: Antissella kalbarriensis Lessard & Woodley, sp.n.
sec.p: ZooBank: http://zoobank.org/C62BBE0F-BA5A-4389-9F79-2982BD3A07A9

Material examined. Holotype ♀, “Kalbarri Gabba/Gabba Gully Rd/ 17 Sep 1981 WA/L.P. Kelsey/(On heath)”; “holotype ♀/Antissella kalbarriensis Lessard & Woodley 2021”; “ANIC Database No./29 037441” [ANIC]. The specimen is in excellent condition.

Paratype: ♀, “Kalbarri W.A/(Shore road)/21 Sep 1981/L.P. Kelsey/(Heath/dunes)”; “paratype ♀/Antissella kalbarriensis Lessard & Woodley 2021”; “ANIC Database No./29 037442” [ANIC]. The specimen is in excellent condition.

Diagnosis. A brilliant green species, distinguished from A. parvidentata and A. quinquecella by the black antennal scapes and pedicels, and all other species by the thorax and abdomen without black, purple or copper colouration, and shorter, broader abdomen that is about 0.8 times as long as wide.

Description. Male. Unknown. Female. Length 5.5–6 mm. Head: Eyes covered in short, moderately dense, brown hair-like setae. Occiput shining golden green, hair-like setae whitish. Frons wide (index 1.9), margins slightly converging ventrally, cuticular surface with reflections of golden green, hair-like setae dense, moderately long, white. Face with reflections of green to coppery gold, hair-like setae long, dense, silvery white. Antennal scapes and pedicels black, with short, black hair-like setae; flagellae brown, darkening black apically, paler on inner surface. Palpi brown, second segment paler yellow brown, hair-like setae moderately long, dense, brown. Proboscis brown, with pale brown hair-like setae.

Thorax: Scutum with brilliant reflections of slight bluish to deep golden green, hair-like setae dense, moderately long, whitish; scutellum same colour and vestiture as scutum, armed with 10 marginal denticles; pleura same colour as scutum, with dense, long, white hair-like setae. Legs with coxae brown, with whitish hair-like setae; femora, tibiae and tarsomeres yellow, somewhat darkening on tarsomeres, hair-like setae long white on femora, short yellowish to white on tibiae and tarsomeres. Wings hyaline; stigma yellow; M3 terminating three quarters distance to wing margin; halteres pale yellowish white, darker on stem.

Abdomen: Relatively short and broad, about 0.8 times as long as wide, with brilliant reflections of slight bluish to deep golden green, hair-like setae dense, appressed short yellowish to white, becoming longer, more erect towards lateral margins. Sternites same colour as tergites, with moderately long, dense, white hair-like setae. Cerci brown, second segment elongate ovoid, twice as long as wide, with dense, long, brown hair-like setae.
Etymology. This specific name is derived from the type locality.
Distribution. Known only from the type locality of Kalbarri, central west coast of WA (Fig. 1).
Remarks. This species appears to be associated with vegetation, since both types were collected from heath.

sec.title: Antissella nigricentralis Lessard & Woodley sp.n.
sec.p: ZooBank: http://zoobank.org/3E395B4E-3091-4288-86FE-039E6E55554B

Material examined. Holotype ♂, “Thomas Riv estuary/Esperance Distr WA/8 Nov. 1977/D.H. Colless/(Malaise Trap)”; “holotype ♀/Antissella nigricentralis Lessard & Woodley 2021”; “ANIC Database No./29 037443” [ANIC]. The specimen is in excellent condition.

Paratypes: 2♀, same data as holotype; “paratype ♀/Antissella nigricentralis Lessard & Woodley 2021”; “ANIC Database No./29 037446” and “ANIC Database No./29 037447” [ANIC]. 2♂, same data as holotype; “6 Nov. 1997”; “paratype ♀/Antissella nigricentralis Lessard & Woodley 2021”; “ANIC Database No./29 037444” and “ANIC Database No./29 037445” [ANIC]. These specimens are in good condition.

Diagnosis. A bluish green species with yellowish legs, similar to A. quinquecella, but distinguished by the black antennae, and separated from all other species by the abdominal tergites with a distinct, wide black medial zone.

Description. Length 5.5–6 mm. Male. Length 5.5–6 mm. Head: Eyes with dense, long, dark brown hair-like setae. Occiput bluish to golden green, hair-like setae long, dense, predominantly black. Frons with cuticular surface black with reflections of golden green, hair-like setae relatively dense, long, brown. Face with reflections of bluish to golden green, hair-like setae dense, long, yellowish white. Antennal scapes and pedicels black, with short, black hair-like setae; flagellae black, slightly paler on inner surface. Palpi black, hair-like setae long, dense, dull whitish on first segment, slightly shorter, black on second segment. Proboscis yellowish to black, hair-like setae dull yellowish white.

Thorax: Deep bluish to golden green, hair-like setae long erect and shorter appressed, dull yellowish, becoming predominantly white at lateral margins; scutellum same colour and vestiture as scutum, armed with 8–12 marginal denticles; pleura same colour as scutum, hair-like setae long, dense, pale yellowish white. Legs with coxae dark yellowish brown, with long, dense, whitish hair-like setae; femora and tibiae pale yellow, hair-like setae white; tarsomeres darker brown, with predominantly short, dense, brown hair-like setae. Wings hyaline to slightly greyish brown; stigma yellowish brown; veins dark yellowish brown; M3 terminating two thirds distance to wing margin; halteres pale yellow.

Abdomen: Deep bluish to golden green, with a distinct, wide black medial zone on all tergites, approximately half the width of the abdomen, hair-like setae short, appressed, golden on black medial zone, becoming longer, more erect and paler yellowish white on lateral margins of all tergites. Sternites golden green with reflections of blue or copper, hair-like setae long, dense, white. Terminalia: gonostyli relatively wide and quadrate, lateral margins slightly curving inwards posteriorly; gonocoxites almost as wide as long, relatively blunted at tips, posterior margin of synsternite with short medial processes, wider than long, separated by a moderately deep concave emargination, gonocoxal apodemes of moderate length, extending beyond anterior margin of gonocoxites, relatively wide, well rounded anteriorly; phallic complex relatively short, not exceeding length of genital capsule, all three lobes slender, medial lobe cylindrical, parameral sheath relatively slender and straight, slightly diverging posteriorly; epandrium relatively narrow, widest at centre, tapering anteriorly, cerci rounded apically, relatively short, in line with proctiger, which is relatively wide and rounded apically.

Female. Length 6 mm. Similar to male, but with the following differences: frons relatively wide (index 1.5–1.7), margins relatively parallel-sided, slightly converging ventrally, cuticular surface with reflections of golden green to copper, hair-like setae relatively spare and sparse, whitish; occiput with shorter, pale yellowish white hair-like setae, becoming longer ventrally; palpi with second segment with black and duller yellowish hair-like setae; legs with paler yellowish tarsomeres; cerci yellowish, second segment elongate ovoid, three times as long as wide, about as long as first, with long, dense, yellowish brown hair-like setae.
Distribution. Known only from the type locality of Thomas River estuary, southern WA (Fig. 1).
Etymology. This specific name is derived from the Latin, nigri, black, and centralis, in the middle, referring to the distinct black medial zone exhibited on the abdominal tergites.

sec.title: Antissella alicespringsensis Lessard & Woodley sp.n.
sec.p: ZooBank: http://zoobank.org/DCE6F088-27AD-4AB2-8788-E4EC0FFD347D

Material examined. Holotype: ♂, “39 km E of/Alice Springs NT/6 Oct 1978/D.H. Colless/(Euc. Blossom)”; “holotype ♂/Antissella alicespringsensis Lessard & Woodley 2021”; “ANIC Database No./29 037448” [ANIC]. The specimen is in excellent condition.

Paratypes: ♀, “23.59S 133.56E/32 km SbyE of/Alice Springs, NT/23 Sept. 1978/J.C. Cardale”; “paratype ♀/Antissella alicespringsensis Lessard & Woodley 2021”; “ANIC Database No./29 037449” [ANIC]. ♀, “24.49S 133.11E, 17 km S of/M(t) Breaden NT/22 Sept. 1978/J.C. Cardale”; “paratype ♀/Antissella alicespringsensis Lessard & Woodley 2021”; “ANIC Database No./29 037450” [ANIC]. ♂, “23.41S 134.15E/39 km E of/Alice Springs, NT/25 Sept. 1978/J.C. Cardale”; “paratype ♂/Antissella alicespringsensis Lessard & Woodley 2021”; “ANIC Database No./29 037451” [ANIC]. ♀, same as previous, “26 Sept. 1978”; “paratype ♀/Antissella alicespringsensis Lessard & Woodley 2021”; “ANIC Database No./29 037453” [ANIC]. ♂, “30 km NW by W of/Alice Springs NT/7 Oct 1978/D.H. Colless”; “paratype ♂/Antissella alicespringsensis Lessard & Woodley 2021”; “ANIC Database No./29 037452” [ANIC].

Diagnosis. A bluish green species with black antennae, similar to A. nigricentralis, but distinguished by the palpi with completely black hair-like setae, contrasting yellow and dark brown banded legs, and abdomen without a black medial zone. This species is also distinguished from A. quinquecella and A. parvidentata by the banded legs and black antennal flagellae.

Description. Length 5.5–7 mm. Male. Length 5.5–7 mm. Head: Hair-like setae moderately long, dense, brown. Occiput with reflections of bluish green, hair-like setae black dorsally, white ventrally. Frons with cuticular surface predominantly black with subtle greenish reflections, hair-like setae long, dense, whitish. Face subshining black, with subtle dull blue reflections, hair-like setae silvery white. Antennal scapes and pedicels black, with short, black hair-like setae; flagellae black, slightly paler on inner surface. Palpi black, both segments with black hair-like setae. Proboscis black with brownish black hair-like setae.

Thorax: Bluish to golden green, hair-like setae predominantly long, erect, white, with a few shorter appressed ones; scutellum same colour and vestiture as scutum, armed with 10–12 marginal denticles; pleura same colour as scutum, with dense, long, mostly erect white hair-like setae. Legs with coxae dark brown to black, with dense, long, white hair-like setae; femora banded, dark brown basal areas contrasting paler yellow apical areas, hair-like setae predominantly white; tibiae banded, pale yellow on basal quarter contrasting dark brown apical area, hair-like setae predominantly white; tarsomeres dark brown, hair-like setae predominantly black, with a ventral zone of short golden brown hair-like setae. Wings hyaline; stigma yellowish brown; veins brown; M3 terminating two thirds to three quarters distance to wing margin; halteres pale yellowish white, darker brown on stem.

Abdomen: Golden green with reflections of copper, hair-like setae on medial zone dense, short, appressed, black, becoming longer, more erect, white laterally. Sternites more bluish green than tergites, hair-like setae long, dense, white. Terminalia: gonostyli with ventral margin more distinctively curved inwards, posterior margin with a slight posterolateral hook-like barb; gonocoxites elongate, slightly longer than wide, posterior margin of synsternite with medial processes distinctly elongate, longer than wide, rounded apically, separated by a deep concave emargination, gonocoxal apodemes of moderate length, extending beyond margin of gonocoxites, relatively wide, relatively rounded anteriorly; phallic complex relatively short, not exceeding length of genital capsule, all three lobes thick, medial lobe cylindrical, parameral sheath expanded anteriorly, sinuous, diverging posteriorly; epandrium relatively broad, noticeably wide medially, tapering anteriorly, cerci relatively wide, short, in line with proctiger, which is broad, triangular, rounded posteriorly.

Female. Length 5.5–6.5 mm. Similar to male, but with the following differences: frons relatively narrow (index 2.2–2.3), margins parallel-sided, only slightly converging ventrally, cuticular surface black with reflections of blue or golden green and copper, hair-like setae dense, long, white on lower two thirds; cerci dark brown, second segment elongate ovoid, about three times as long as wide, hair-like setae moderately long, yellowish brown.
Distribution. Known only from the Alice Springs region, central nt (Fig. 1).
Etymology. This specific name is derived from the collection locality.

Remarks. There is some degree of morphological variation in the specimens examined. Some female specimens have a deeper blue colouration of the thorax and abdomen than the greener males. One specimen 39 km east of Alice Springs (ANIC 29-037451) has slightly more concolorous pale yellow tibiae than the remaining specimens with banded pale yellow and darker brown tibiae. This is currently interpreted as intraspecific variation. This species appears to be associated with Eucalyptus, as the holotype was collected from Eucalyptus flowers and may have an unknown role in pollination.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: Three of the species are expected to be directly impacted by the devastating 2019/2020 spring and summer bushfires that burned Australia: A. purprasina is known only from the type locality of Lamington National Park, Qld, that was severely burned; the two more widespread species A. parvidentata and A. quinquecella are known from several national parks that burned, including Namadgi National Park, act, but are likely to recover based on populations spread across southeast Australia. The impact of these fires on the species is unknown. The recorded geographical distributions of A. alicespringsensis, A. elongata, A. kalbarriensis, A. nigricentralis and A. ottensorum did not burn and were unaffected by these fires. Now that the species are officially named, described and included in an updated key to species, we hope that they can be formally included in future bushfire recovery surveys and phylogenetic studies.

ack.title: Acknowledgements
ack.p: Authors would like to thank: Christine Lambkin, Karin Koch and Susan Wright (qm), Russell Cox and Derek Smith (ams), Peter Hudson (sam), Justin Bartlett and Desley Tree (qdpc), Ken Walker and Catriona McPhee (nmva), Martin Hauser (California Department of Agriculture), Loïc Matile (deceased, mnhn), John Chainey (nhmuk), Richard Glatz (rgc) and Cathy Byrne and Simon Grove (tmag) for providing access to and loaning material; Ben Parslow (sama) for providing database numbers for material deposited from the rbc; Steve Lingafelter (United States Department of Agriculture) for imaging the types of A. parvidentata and A. quinquecella; Robyn Meier (anic) for providing training in BioLink, and; Nicole Fisher and Noreen Tasleem (anic) for digitising specimens. This paper is a product of the Australian Biological Resources Study (abrs) National Taxonomy Research Grant Program project “A phylogeny, systematic revision and key to the genera of Australian Soldier Flies (Diptera: Stratiomyidae)” (RF214-30) and the Australian American Fulbright Commission Specialist Grant “Training the next generation of Australian entomologist through research, fieldwork and scientific writing”.
